caption: Went early on a Friday for lunch, so that we could head to the Warhol exhibit at the AIC before it closed. My companion noted how many of the Restaurant Week items had beans in them, so we ordered off the usual menu. I had the Crispy Brussel Sprouts ($13) which had to have been shaved on a machine, they were so thinly sliced. I loved the char and the cheese, and it was a huge portion, although it was a bit salty for me. To counter that, I had the Debbie Harry, ($10+) a crazy Warhol-inspired dessert that was a chocolate malt (not sweet enough!) topped with banana-flavored cotton candy, with a side of fries. I'd already reached my sodium limit, so I gave the fries to my friend, along with the chipotle mayo that came to dip my sprouts in.
Both me and my husband got food poisoning after eating food from here.
I attended a private event here. The space was amazing. I especially liked the various art pieces, which I assume were part of the museum collection, that were on display.

(Translated by Google) Slow attention, small portions. The food is well prepared, although it could be better. The place is nice, the attention is friendly. I think it is not recommended, it is preferable to look for something outside the museum if you are looking for a good gastronomic experience.  (Original) Atención lenta, porciones reducidas. La comida está bien preparada, aunque podría ser mejor. El local es bonito, la atención es amable. Creo que no es recomendable, es preferible buscar algo fuera del museo si se busca una experiencia gastronomica de buen nivel.
I wish I could be more positive, but the food on the Valentine's day 5 course menu was simply not good. Perhaps the regular menu is better, I hope?
Dirk Denison Architects did a great job with the interior design of the restaurant! Amazing spot to eat after visiting the Art Institute with a great view of Grant Park and the city surroundings!

We really enjoyed 2/3 of the food we tried. The drinks are good, inventive menu, and the service was great. Missing stars because of the cleanliness of the restaurant. I’m sure all of the white is hard to keep up with, but we were near a window that was loaded with crumbs and dirt. The floor around us was in similar condition, and all of the furniture was in bad shape. I’ll try it again, but am hoping to have a better experience.

I live visiting Terzo Piano after spending time at the Art Institute. The restaurant is open, full of light emanating from the massive windows that give you breathtaking views of the city. Better than the ambiance and the views are the food and service. I definitely recommend.

The witty and fun staff made my "not birthday" birthday lunch quite memorable. Great location a ambiance and food. The current Andy Warhol special menu was really fun with some unique and delicious options. Would definitely visit again, particularly for a lighter lunch meal.
Loved the Warhol inspired desserts!

Uncooked salmon and unseasoned salmon. Udon was overly sweet and salty, with size just enough for a toddler.  Hamburger was ok.  But, for the price please go elsewhere.  May be all the chefs were not working, I.e off on the day of my visit.  Awful experience.  Only fill the water half full? Is that a new trend?  How did it get such hi rating I would never know.
Very Contemporary
Good
The pumping and ricotta ravioli are to die for. The service with keshana was really friendly.
A lovely restaurant with a fun menu and a great view.
Chic and delicious with excellent food

When I am at the Art Institute I often eat at Terzo Piano. This time I ate rabbit cannelloni (very well prepared), bergamot madeleines. I drank a glass of prosecco and finished with an espresso. Service was good though the restaurant was full. When the weather is nice the large terrasse with skyline view of Chicago is very pleasant. it is not cheap but worth it considering the quality of the food and the location.
A Fair restaurant in the art institute of chicago. Rainy or not, out the terrace seats are much better than inside ones. Foods are fair but service and coffee is good enough drop by.

Took awhile to find an employee who could direct us to the 3rd floor of the Modern Building in the Art Institute. Quiet, restful and great light. Food was excellent and service was very good. Had a great raspberry lemonade. The lamb burgers were not overcooked, but medium rare and very tasty. The halibut special was just a bit overcooked, but very flavorful. The flan was amazing.
Loved it
Pricey place but excellent food and service

The Art Institute deserves a better restaurant.  Roasted Tomato soup was too much like canned tomato puree, and the "taste of spring" (on the menu in late September?) pasta was more capers than pasta.  Wines by the glass were good, at least.
Great food, great and calm place, ideal for à break Art Institute' visit
(Translated by Google) Nice place, good old people, good charcuterie  (Original) Belo local, bons vonhos, boa charcuterie
(Translated by Google) BEAUTIFUL VIEW  (Original) HERMOSA VISTA
Excellent
(Translated by Google) The food is delicious!! And it has an excellent view!  (Original) La comida está deliciosa!! Y tiene una excelente vista!

Great restaurant located right in the west wing of the  Art Institute of Chicago. Spacy, natural light and great city view.  The lamb burger and 🐙 octopus were savory and cook just right!  The seafood spaghetti was just so so.
Food and drinks was excellent.
Delicious!
I remember I enjoyed the meals I’ve had here (mostly celebrations of some sort) but I honestly can’t remember any of the dishes. The ambiance is really nice with nice views and access to the rooftop.
Had a wonderful lunch after walking through the art institute
This is a great place for a wedding reception
Try the lamb burger

My experience at Terzo Piano was delightful. The food was fresh and flavorful. I will definitely come back. I had the seared trout with chimichurri and fresh greens atop. My dessert was a chocolate hazelnut tarte. The environment was open and airy. A wonderful place to dine at in the loop.

A lovely, intimate place with ok food and great music. I paid $20 for a loaf and bread and a little thing of pate' and 3 things of butter. Not thrilled but the experience was very nice. I enjoy going here immensely and will enjoy again.

This place was really incredible. The food, service and ambiance was perfect. We had a large group of 10 people sitting in the outside seating area and we still felt like we received good attention from the servers. The food was excellent and was one of my favorite meals I've ever had in Chicago and I absolutely plan on coming back here on my next trip. Despite all the great things, the prices were surprisingly not that high either. I highly recommend this place for brunch.  Dishes I can personally vouch for: Crab Fries, Fried Green Tomato Benedict, Shakshuka, Pancakes.

The view and ambiance was very nice.  However, we were disappointed for the sunday brunch menu and the service. We ordered our food based on the waiter's recommendations; Shakshuka and Crab Fries. The Shakshuka was too sour and didn't taste well. The Crab Fries had barely no "crab" in it and almost 80% was of just McDonald's fries. They were both totally not worth the money.  The waiter was unkind. He kept passing by our table even after he surely saw us trying to order and get our check and pay for it. He wouldn't talk back to what we said to him, and just came by to pour water.  Also, I reserved our brunch as my birthday, and received nothing. I remember reading a review that someone had received a plate of cake, but for us no one mentioned a word about it.  I would say the prices were for the view and the "modern and calm" ambiance, not the food or service.
Great food and good service.
Always great!
(Translated by Google) Very good atmosphere and quality in the dishes. Excellent attention  (Original) Muy buen ambiente y calidad en los platos. Una atención excelente
Excellent food and great service!!! Pls the lake front bridge view is sick!!!
This modern American Fine dining restaurant serves creatives plates with quality ingredients and a twist of art combines to mimic the current Art exhibit of the season.
Expensive, $130 for lunch for 3.  Well worth it.
Food is far better than what you expect for a museum restaurant - it's actually really really good. Views from the rooftop portion are incredible. Location can't be beat.
The best almond torte with lavender icecream
Lovely lunch spot and delicious cocktails inspired by Manet.

Certainly artistic and open floor plan, minimalistic in design, so is the food presentation, delicious, but overpriced and small portions, the lentil soup is not traditional, i.e. less lentil more other veggies, light but did the trick of serving as a nutritional snack.
Great food, nice service, amazing views

The service was really good at the start, but the staff quickly developed an attitude. The portion size for my meal was very small, being quite unfilling. My friends said that their food was good, but mine was not worth the high price tag at all. The soda was also served without carbonation at all, making for a stale taste. They seem to also not like giving separate checks for some reason, which is very inconvenient for five friends paying separately. We had to essentially demand separate checks, which they were reluctant to give.
Very small portions and prices are really high.
Great place to get away from the crowds and a beautiful view of the city. I tried the eggplant that was lightly breaded with panko with pickled eggplant on top of that. It was perfect
A great lunch in a great location
Simply amazing food, portions are just right, deserts are to die for.
(Translated by Google) Ideal to accompany a day at the Art Institute  (Original) Ideal para acompañar un día en el Instituto de Arte
The appetizers and entrees we're slightly under-seasoned this time, but the cocktails and desserts were really delicious. The atmosphere, per usual, was lovely.

Stopped here for lunch. A delightful Morell Salad,  focaccia bread and a glass of wine. The clean, modern ambiance was enhanced by a farm to table menu that didn't disappoint, an excellent wine list and excellent service.
A bit disappointing!

This was soooo desapointing. They need to improve soo much. The quality of the food is so very low. I would rather eat at Mc Donalds than in here. We had to return most of the dishes. Hope they do something about this place.

2 -3 hours in museum halls and you are tired, can’t already feel the art, the mood , the beauty – you need to relax. So – there was a Terzo Piano Restaurant  ( not easy to find on schema – better ask employees there). And here we are  - elegant place in sophisticated design, light furniture, airy space …You can see the bar but kitchen …covered from customer’s eyes . Good sign! Don't remember if I saw Piano there . The meal , mostly Italian also looks contemporary. Small portions  with a touch of…art.. We got soups – roaster cauliflower , grilled octopus  and grilled chicken with charred peal onions. Every dish was delicious, tasty  for our joy. We felt relaxed , exchanged impressions of the pictures we have seen….Nice atmosphere, pleasant drinks. There was also some dessert – you see what is left on the picture. Do not remember what it was. But good. Come to watch Art and get some tasty bite in the same kind of Culinary Art. You wouldn’t regret when you did.

Service, food, presentation all impeccable. This is one of my favorite places to have lunch and a glass of wine. You can certainly dine alone, with friends or simply on business. This place will not disappoint. My favourite menu items are the mushroom flatbread, shrimp and crab salad, the roasted chicken and the cauliflower. I doubt whatever is ordred, it won't disappoint.
Ambience

Nice place to have lunch while visiting Art Institute of Chicago Museum. I had mushroom salad and it was delicious. The waiter who served me was very polite and helpful as well as efficient. I think all waiters there are good.

We went as part of a food tour. The atmosphere was awesome!  We had 5 of the 7 new desserts. The chef came out to explain them. They all were delicious and had many depths of flavor...highly recommend!
Food and ambiance are unrivaled
Modern, classy Art Institute restaurant. Delicious menu and great service. Highly recommend.
One of the best museum restaurants in the world.  Great menu choices, skilled staff and an excellent space inside or outside.
Cool place after a visit in the Art Institute

Servers were pleasant but overall inattentive.  People in our section were getting upset that it took 20 mins for someone to pour water, much less take an order.  And the restaurant was definitely not busy for Thursday lunch.  The food was just ok: my duck was served VERY rare, and was cold.  My wife's pasta dish had gone cold, too-- leaving the sauce less-than-appetizing.  We came to the conclusion that the server had forgotten our food in the kitchen.  And we weren't sure how long the wait would be for new, appropriately prepared food to come out, so we didn't say anything.  The empty charcuterie board that we had as an appetizer was never cleared from the table until our bill was brought.  After the house manager got a complaint from the table next to us, we saw him talk to the server in our area, but nothing really changed.  I ordered another glass of wine halfway through my lunch that showed up 5 minutes after I had finished eating.  It was a disappointing experience, but still better than waiting in the cattle line for the cafeteria downstairs, at least that is what we tried to convince ourselves.  Next time, we'll go to the Corner Bakery across the street instead.
Wonderful shrimp, frisee salad, flatbread.
Excellent food and personal service. Very nice views of Chicago out of full length windows on 2 sides.
(Translated by Google) Very good  (Original) Muy bueno
Amazing food here. Always good spot to check out. Try different courses if possible. Creative dishes by great chefs.

I was so excited to have lunch here while visiting the Art Institute. The view is amazing and the space is bright and clean. The server was pleasant, but did not check on us after our meal arrived.  The whiskey ginger cocktail was very nice. The burger was great and loved the fries.  The Cobb salad was horrible. Nothing had any flavor, from the meat to the dressing. Salt did not even add flavor. The server was nice to comp the salad, even though he did not check to see how the meal was. We had to get his attention to tell him the salad was bland.
Best Ravioli I've ever ate!
Great place to stop in for a meal. I especially reccomend stopping in for lunch before going to the museum. We had a great time, go check it out

Only gave it a 5 star so people would see this! If I could give a 0 stars I could! If you are young you get strange looks like you don’t belong and you get ignored. My husband and I (20 & 21 years old) went here while visiting Chicago, when we got here we were welcomed by a nice lady at the front and seated. Once seated we didn’t get served- after 15 minutes of sitting with no menus or anything the lady in the front brought us waters. After that it took another 5-10 minutes for our actual server to get to us and take our order, after taking our order we did not see our waitress again until we were done eating and ready to leave. After asking for the bill it was another 10 minutes until we got our bill (it also was not busy at all) There was a lady that called over the manager and said they are mistreating us but nothing changed.. this was a horrible and uncomfortable experience and I will definitely not be returning!

Amazing food in a friendly atmosphere!! We went for restaurant week and they had an extensive menu of homeade pastas, meats and seafood to choose from.  Our waiter was courteous and helpful in providing suggestions. By far the best Italian food I have had in the city in a long time.

Good food, good service, good cocktails; in a nice, open and bright space. As a semi regular visitor to the a.a. my advice is....  Don't expect.to be able to just slide on in here to eat while visiting in the art institute.... reservations are pretty important Most tables are filled all the time, esp. In weekends.
Food was fantastic
(Translated by Google) Fantastic museum!  (Original) Fantastico museo!
Great place to eat while visiting the Art
Wonderful food and service@
Chef Carolina is amazing!!! Everything is so delicious, especially the tuna squid ink dish...

Nice atmosphere, fairly inattentive service and mixed marks on food. Some of the items we had such as the duck and the flat bread were excellent with complimentary flavors which brought out the best in the ingredients. However one of the mains with lamb and pasta had an overpowering acidic sauce that drowned out any flavors the lambs had. Overall still a good experience and quite reasonably priced for what and where it is.
Elegant dining at the art institute love the minimalist design and location can't be beat. As in all of these types of restaurants you really do not get a large portion just nice artsy food

Came here for restaurant week. The cauliflower soup, ink squid pasta, and toffee cake was fantastic. Also recommend the cheese and olives. The restaurant has great view of the Art Institute. Modern and classic ambience.
Delicious flat bread
The view is better than the food.  Average food at expensive prices.
A very pleasant quiet environment and excellent food

This is my wife's favorite lunch spot. Even if you aren't enjoying a day at the Art Institute, it is worth a stop. The Fried Cauliflower dish I ate was amazing. Don't go her if you're rushed. Come and relax and soak it in.
Beautiful restaurant, as expected in an art gallery. Everything from the food & service to the knives and forks was exquisite.
A great enhancement to a visit at the Art Institute. Superb food and libations.
The food is pretty good. Service could be quite a bit more attentive. I like the seasonal house-made sodas. Lots of sunlight.
Great food and service. Not cheap but worth the price.
Beautiful and cool place to have lunch with friends
Fine Restaurant, good food, pleasant service.
The flatbreads are delicious!
(Translated by Google) Very nice place, Italian food, above the museum with great views of Chicago!  (Original) Très bel endroit, cuisine italienne, au dessus du musée avec superbe vue sur Chicago !
Fancy place
Awesome Food. I can deliver that this restaurant is excellent.
Creative but rich-flavoured. Simple but seduced. Expensive but worth every dollar.
Fancy schmancy desserts

I really had fun at this place, the food is amazing, plus the restrooms were not bad for public. It was a little cold inside, so that was not the most enjoyable. The vibe is good. I will most definitely think about going back once again if I get the opportunity. Me as well as my friend got the combo as well as we were not disappointed. My one idea is to maintain the cool exterior. Laters!
(Translated by Google) Delicious.  (Original) Delicioso.
A real foodie joint.
Nice restaurant. we
Wonderful evening of wine tasting & appetizers.
Good food. Nice vibe.
Very good place for brunch,lunch, coffee before or after visiting the museum. Reasonable prices, eclectic environment.
Amazing!
Amazing food, super chilled and relaxed
Excellent food, drinks, and service.
Very tasty food, good service, nice views.
Food was horrible
I was so happy with my new experience with terzp piano,Fabulous staff and great services i had.Thank You!!
Beautiful view, pasta was delicious

(Translated by Google) Good food. Nice views of Chicago buildings and good service. Perfect to finish the visit of a great Museum!  (Original) Buena comida. Lindas vistas de los edificios de Chicago y buen servicio.  Perfecto para terminar la visita de un gran Museo!
I have been to this restaurant twice and both times the service was far below what one would expect and the food was mediocre.
Great setting, wonderful service, fabulous meal start to finish.
Lovely cafe in the Chicago Art Museum.  Indoor and outdoor seating.
Worst service, poor quality of food, overpriced.  9/7/2018 Funny, somehow my original review was gone and what’s left was above. Wondering who can do it? Google??
Not a huge fan. Ok location and half decent food.

This is one of those spots I love to visit even though the food frankly isn't spectacular. It's good food, if somewhat overpriced for the portion sizes, but the setting and atmosphere are what I enjoy: great views of the surrounding downtown area and a fun modern white theme inside. The flatbreads are usually tasty.
Food and drink are always good service is getting worse.
Very good food, large portions! You can enjoy the restaurant without paying admission to the Art Institute of Chicago.
A modern and contemporary vibe, paired with refined cuisine allows for a great dining experience, however lacks the more upscale dining crowd due to the Museum.
Great views, good food, trout was great.
Great food but not worth the price.

Yes, it's pretty expensive.  I was glad I had a reservation.  I got there 15 minutes early and had to wait a minute, but saw many people come up and ask and be told it would be at least a 40 minute wait.  As far as the portion size goes, just don't expect them to bring you a giant plate piled high with filler.  The meal is carefully made and nothing is waste.  It's enough to fill you up without making you feel like you need to loosen your belt a notch, which frankly, is nice if you are going to continue touring the gallery or the city.  The dessert was impeccable.

Overpriced for small portions of unimaginative food....$21 for a small Cobb salad is outrageous. Don't waste you money & there isn't even a view!  The Rose was the only good thing about the restaurant.
Very nice setting and tasty food
I stopped here for business lunch. The service was great and the food was good.

(Translated by Google) Inventive cuisine, original and balanced tastes, with (little) nods to classic American specialties. I had chosen pieces of fried cockerel, Kentucky chiken style, accompanied by a cuckoo flavored with coriander and sumac (the latter, masked by coriander). The portions are sufficient but do not allow the usual doggy bag. As the Valrhona dessert ordered was not finally available, the lemon cream dessert was served to me with a glass of limoncello (kindly offered).  (Original) Une cuisine inventive, des goûts originaux et équilibrés, avec des (petits) clins d'œil aux spécialités classiques américaines. J'avais choisis des morceaux de coquelet frit, façon Kentucky chiken, accompagnée par un coucous parfums au coriandre et au sumac (ce dernier, masqué par le coriandre). Les portions sont suffisantes mais ne permettent pas l'habituel doggy bag. Le dessert au Valrhona commandé n'ayant pas été finalement disponible, celui à la crème au citron m'a été servi avec un verre de limoncello (gracieusement offert).
Have a bite and nice selection of wines
Delightful food and great service
Beautiful place and the food OMG like OMG
Lovely place in the Modern Wing of the Art Institute
So comfortable on a beautiful summer afternoon. Service & offerings we're fabulous!
Surprisingly good for a museum restaurant.
A wonderful spot in the Art Institute.  Modern styling and very special food which by nature is not too much
Good soup. Friendly old men.
(Translated by Google) The food is good, but the restaurant, especially the Chicago skyline from the terrace, is great.  (Original) 食事もおいしいですが、このレストラン、特にテラス席からのシカゴのスカイラインは最高です。

Very pleasant.  Well lit and bright.  Fine dining.  This is NOT for "kids" nor should it be.  You won't get hotdogs and fries.  There are other places at the Art Intstitue that suit children menus nicely. Gnocchi was very good.  Portions a bit small, but so tasty.  $20 for pasta in "fine dining" is very in-line with other comparable restaurants.  Handicapped accessible (elevators and open tables). Wait staff was friendly and attentive.  Manager was interested in feedback and asked how or dining experience was.  I'll definitely return.
Beautiful setting kitchen good but not great
Eclectic selection; a bit pricey.  The hot and sour soup was **fantastic**. The ambiance was rather nice too.  I even enjoyed the selection of beer & wine.  But as for what passes for service...woof!

Lovely bright dining  with lots of windows! Service was very good. Food was average yet good; prices were high. Adorable artistic individual teapot!! I would recommend this restaurant for a relaxing lunch with others.

We used to look forward to lunching here in between the exhibitions, but my experience today was bad. The place was half filled and the service was painfully slow. The quality of food has dropped dramatically that makes me think, this is either new management or chefs or a bit of both! The cauliflower soup with apple mouse tasted like a blended potato and the mousse had the coloring of a cheap food color. They claimed it was colored with beets, but beets never leave an orangish red stain! I ordered the shrimp salad which was inspid. My son ordered the burger which was over salted and tasted heavily of the bun and nothing else. When we told the waiter he said could replace it but thankfully we didn’t as the experience we had was not unique, when I read other reviews, they had complaints about the sub standard burger. I  was surprised that the waiter did not take the cost off the burger or reduce it marginally. My advice is eat along Michigan Ave and avoid having a similar experience as us.
Excellent and well-presented food options, prices very reasonable for the quality and service.
Wonderful experience
Good restaurant inside the Art Institute.

Half of the menu was incomprehensible. As far as I can tell it wasn't even properly written in a human language. But instead a mishmash of Italian French and English.  Expect to easily spend $20 a person. With tiny portion sizes but somewhat better than average flavors.
Exceptional food in an architecturally noteworthy setting, and the service is impeccable. A favorite!
Beautiful view, great food.
Good service and nice environment.
Least appealing menu I have ever seen. Definitely not kid friendly. However my family seemed to like it and the view was great but the burger I had was 70% bun and the bun wasn't even that good!
Outstanding food.  Not your typical museum cafe.
Shared a bery nice meal with my daughter after cruising through the museum. fresh light lunch that keeps you moving.
Appetizers were amazing. Event buffet was okay.
(Translated by Google) Excellent gourmet food  (Original) Excelente comida gourmet

Our waiter was knowledgeable and very communicative. He made great recommendations and the staff willingly accommodated dietary needs. The lovely space made a great canvas for the beautiful, fresh, and sumptuous summer salads we had.    The wine and special exhibit-inspired (Gauguin) dessert completed our visionary dining experience.
I had never been disappointed in this place.  Always excellent food and service
Great atmosphere. Food was mediocre and extremely over priced for the quailty. Expect little satisfaction after signing your check. See my picture of the Smoky Cioppino.
Some good some bad. Good cocktails. Good food, but some is so salty it was hard to finish. Come on chef, focus, please.

I ordered a crab salad/soup. Two stars because it tasted okay, what there was of it. This restaurant used to offer reasonably sized portions. My "entree" wouldn't have even qualified as an appetizer. I had to order bread (and pay extra) so I wouldn't walk away completely hungry. A blot on the Art Institute's reputation.
Mediocre. Wanted it to Be nicer
Excellent ambiance but mediocre food. Still worth it.

Not what I expected from the hype I heard from friends. It was pleasant enough with an ok food experience. We also felt rushed, but that can be an individual server issue as well, something we have never experienced in the outdoor lower level cafe. I would dine there again if in the building for an exhibit.
Pretty good, not perfect.
Nice space. Lamb burger was tasty but tasty but maybe not worth the $20.
Great value, delicious prix fixe lunch, attentive service and imaginative, tasty food. Beautiful airy space, very much recommended.

The restaurant was not very busy, except for a party in the rear yet it took at least 10 minutes to get a glass of ice for our water because the ice in the pitchers had melted. When our food arrived it was cold and we had to send it back and when the food came back it still was not hot. Our waitress took an entree off our bill. Our other complaint was that we asked for bread and was told they ran out due to two parties earlier and the kitchen didn't want to make more because it was late. It was at least 40 minutes before closing. When we spoke to the manager he told us that there was indeed bread, the kitchen had made it several minutes back and he offered to bring some to our table. I had, at this point, finished my meagerly portioned meal. All in all it was not a pleasant dining experience. The manager apologized, offering to buy us lunch the next time we came. However it is doubtful that we'll take him up on his offer. Not at all impressed.

The restaurant sits atop the modern wing of the Art Institute. The space is completely open, quite large, and features views of the surrounding Millennium Park area. The food is more of an accompaniment to the fantastic space. The duck flatbread was a bit too heavy and greasy while the pork shoulder was a bit too simplistic in flavor.
(Translated by Google) good to eat  (Original) 好吃

Great place for a buy-out event such as a wedding, but for day-to-day dining, it's a pass.  Food crawls from the kitchen and leaves you wondering why anything so pedestrian took so long to prepare. I wasn't particularly wowed by the food but I was definitely irritated by the price tag.

So happy that I checked this place out! Who knew there was such a gem in the middle of the Art Institute? The indoor part of the bar really reinforces the message that you're eating in the middle of a museum, but in a really cool way. The outdoor area is a clean, neat, modern open-space area with a sculpture off to the side and a beautiful view of the skyscrapers behind Millennium Park.  Originally came here for drinks, but discovered that the food here is awesome. Their rosemary bread is freaking delicious---- I love the saltiness mixed when it's dipped in olive oil. I was pleasantly surprised to see that they had eggplant fries, which made me feel like I was being somewhat healthy while indulging. Their salad and a couple of their other dishes were pretty solid as well, so I would definitely come back to try more items off their menu. Service was great as well--- our server was very courteous and prompt.

My girlfriend and I attempted to have lunch on a Thursday. There were not many people dining and we ordered charcuterie, the cheese plate and flat bread. We overheard our waiter telling other tables that the hamburger takes about 20 minutes to cook and if they were ok with that he would put in their order.  When he placed our order he said it be right up without giving us any indication of a preparation time. We watched tables around us receive their orders, including the 20 minute hamburgers and still did not receive our food. After 45 minutes we called the waiter over and he had no idea where our food was and said he would have to get a manager. After an hour the manager brought over some pickles and let us know they had started working on our food. After an 80 minutes we ended up leaving without ever receiving anything we had ordered or an apology for the lack of service.
Great atmosphere, excellent food - make me feel so sophisticated.

I'd heard and read good things, but we had to try it for ourselves.  Attached to The Art Institute, Terzo Piano has its own entrance - a 200 foot bridge - which is as exciting to walk over as any other attraction in the surrounding area.  I had the cavatelli in brodo; it was delicious! The house made ketchup which accompanied the french fries was delightful! The service, which I'm very critical of, was dynamite!  Definitely NOT a tourist trap! Just a wonderful restaurant in an amazing location.
